title: 2025 Bespoked UK Day 01: Alfano, Clandestine, Condor, Craft, Creature, Drust, Medusa, Singular, Sturdy – John Watson
content:
Bespoked UK has long been on John’s “must-see” list of framebuilder showcases, and this year, he finally got to attend the UK event. Read on for a jam-packed gallery, oozing with fillets, finishes, and more from some of his favorites at the 2025 Bespoked UK!

The Radavist thanks Tailfin for supporting our 2025 Bespoked UK coverage and our independent Reportage!

Set and Setting: Victoria Baths

The venue sets the vibe for a show, and Bespoked UK’s home base of the Victoria Baths in Manchester is hands down one of the best venues I’ve been to. Ignore the flaking (possible) lead paint, asbestos, and mold. Instead, appreciate the tile work, stained glass, and decades of patina.

With infinite colors, textures, and interestingness, I found myself getting lost in the details of the venue as much as the Beautiful Bicycles on display. Let’s check out my first day’s selects in alphabetical order…

Alfano Frameworks Razzle TT Bike

This might be my first time trial bikes that I’ve documented in the almost twenty years of shooting bicycles. Leicester’s Alfano Frameworks brought his personal time trail bike to Bespoked UK this year. The bike was literally fresh from the painter and assembled minutes before the showcase opened to builders for setup last Thursday.

Pete Alfano explained to me the relevance of British time trials as I carefully balanced the bike on my display stand. It seems British “open” road racing was banned in the 1890s due to someone complaining, resulting in a growth in time trial races. As a method for evading police, racers could ride in a group and allow each individual to wear all-black while riding the course to avoid detection from the authorities.

As such, this is Pete’s personal bike; he’s been a lifelong fan of time trial racing and decided it was time to build himself a new bike. The all-steel 10.8 kilo bike features steel fairings and a stunning “Razzle Dazzle” warship-inspired paint, laid down by Chroma Paintworks. This bike won best paint at the show.

@AlfanoFrameworks

Clandestine Pinion Touring Bike

You had me at olive drab. You had me at rim brakes. You had me at quill stem. Pi, you blew me away with the Pinion gearbox! Pi Manson is Clandestine, a Devon-based builder with a wonderful touch for color and detail. This tourer was built for a client in Australia who lives on a boat and wanted a bike inspired by paratroopers’ bikes from WWII.

The semi-gloss olive drab paint accentuates the thick raw fillet brazing without distracting from the fine detailing: scalloped seat stays, a bi-plane fork, steerer lockout, custom racks, stem, and cable hangers. All of these alone would make for a very tasteful machine, but it’s the dichotomy of these timeless details contrasted with the Pinion gearbox that made this bike a show-stopper.

In fact, the only thing more wonderful than this bike is the human who built it. We had a lovely conversation as it was the last bike I shot of the day, with the sunlight breaking through the clouds for one brief moment.

@Clandestine

Condor Cycles Bivio Gravel Bike

Founded in 1948, Condor Cycles has long been a staple in London. Its line of house label metal frames are handmade in Italy. While the brand displayed heaps of shiny new bikes, this Bivio gravel bike matched the tiles of the Victoria Baths perfectly and had evidence of being ridden. With aisles upon aisles of pristine, brand new bikes, it was nice to document a bike that had some miles on it.

The Bivio frameset retails for £1,599.99, comes in six sizes, is made from Columbus Spirit and Spirit HSS steel, 43 mm tire clearance, and a geometry tuned for off-road riding and adventures.

@CondorCycles

Craft Bikes Ti Hardtail

Jim and Chloe run Craft Bikes out of their Hythe, Kent-based workshop. Founded in 2017, Craft is a 100% bespoke framebuilder, utilizing 3D printed titanium components and custom geometries, tailor-fit for their clients’ needs. As evident in this titanium hardtail, the 3D printed components blend seamlessly with the butted titanium tubeset, accentuating the process’ possibilities.

The internal routing is clean, entering the head tube at a reinforced and lipped port, with ample tire clearance provided by the yoke and elegant dropouts, allowing for a nice-n-neat rear brake caliper to be tucked in between the stays. Craft can make this model with internal or external routing, for electronic drivetains or cable-actuated, and in any geometry. On display, the bike features a long front center, 65º head angle, 74º seat angle, and 140 mm of travel. Hope Tech graciously provided the components in the brand’s new pewter finish.

Throughout the day, I struck gold with the lighting, but these photos are some of my favorite…

@CraftBikes

Creature Cycles Galago MX V2 Full Suspension

Social media connects builders with new audiences and, in this case, media! I was served James’ development of the Galago MX V2 bike via my Instagram explore page and was immediately hooked. The use of 3D sintered components from 316L stainless is one thing but the whole modus operandi of Creature Cycles was very appealing for a number of reasons. First, I love UK steel full-suspension bikes. But Creature has gone a few steps further than others in the space. Tyler designed the bike to pivot on poly bushings, similar to what you’d find in a leaf spring shackle in a 4×4 or pickup truck. After playing around with all sorts of bearing types, he decided to use bushings for this version of the Galago. Second, his stem is a work of art in itself. The buttressing and stainless steel finish is reminiscent of an ancient artifact. Third, I can’t get enough of the gusset… and that paint!

All these are obvious details but upon further inspection, you’ll notice the diamond-shaped pivot points, counter-sunk into the linkage parts. These are tapered – like a square tapered crank spindle – resulting in a press-fit connection that is secure, even if you remove the bolts. Utilizing MX, or mixed wheel sizes, the Galago has a trail/enduro geometry and just looks like it wants to grip and plop down the trail thanks to the mono linkage design.

James learned to fillet at the Bicycle Academy but taught himself how to TIG weld. He welded the rear triangle, but Gavin White from Coal Bikes took on the front triangle. He joked that his welds are messy compared to Gavin’s. However, I felt like it was all part of the Galago’s charm and the collaborative energy that resonates through the UK builder community. Lee Morgan’s artwork just adds to this bike’s mystique. Hope Tech was very generous to James and flossed the bike out with beautiful pewter components.

Well done, mate.

@CreatureCycles

Drust Cycles Mini Bike Tandem

Konstantin from Drust Cycles brought his A-game once again to Bespoked, upping the ante on the “Golden Age of Tiny Bikes” with a not-so-tiny 20″ wheeled tandem. To further push the envelope, the bike is coupled via a few different methods. There’s an S&S coupler at the rear chainstay, two bolts at the rear seat cluster, and then a Ritchey Breakaway-inspired front seat cluster.

The captain cluster actually uses the seatpost for clamping, which buts into the sleeved seat tube, ensuring Konstantin’s saddle height is exact. If someone were to buy this bike from him, he could trim the seatpost to their saddle height in the future. Not pictured are front racks and rear racks, which he omitted from the show to highlight the bike itself. Oh, and those racks will carry dogs, too!

The ombré faded paint, beautiful raw, overlapping fillets, and colors elevated this bike top to my personal list of favorite all-time show bikes. Konstantin himself is a gem of a human, too, so that makes it all the more special.

The build features a 3×3 hub in the rear, a Gramm framebag, generous parts from Hope Tech, G2 Byschulz Parallelogram Suspension Seatposts, and a SON system, which was sent for free, according to SON, “as long as the bike design doesn’t suck; then you have to pay for it.” The German hub dynamo makers delivered this news to Drust in a tone that was maybe joking, maybe not… but winning the Best in Show award at Bespoked UK must count for something, no?

@DrustCycles

Medusa Cycles Road Bike

Pete from Medusa Cycles made his debut on The Radavist last year at Bespoked UK. This year, he brought this stunning road bike. He learned how to fillet, braze, and build bikes from Butterfield Bicycles, a tiny shop in Manchester, and has been building for four years. While comparatively a short amount of time, Pete hasn’t minced his figurative words with this bike, which exhibits a number of clever and unique details.

A bilam seat cluster is coupled with a triple triangle seat stay that is sleeved around the top tube to add some stiffness to the bike. For more bottom bracket stiffness, he’s used a double chainstay, with the top stay bent and fillet brazed to the lower stay. The bike was painted by Pete in his shop and features intricately adorned oak leaves, as well as the Medusa text. Pete’s also a bit of a brush artist himself, painting his Medusa sign hanging in his booth.

If there is one bike that reflects the Victoria Baths through ornate beauty, it’s this Medusa road. Well done, Pete.

@MedusaCycles

Singular Cycles  Track Bike

While Singular Cycles is perhaps best known for its drop-bar mountain bikes, adventure touring bikes, and gravel bikes, I couldn’t help myself with this stunning track bike they brought to the showcase. Founder Sam Alison was baiting me with this one! Sam’s personal bike sports a set of Reynolds carbon rims with Phil Wood hubs, radially laced, and arrived at the show with Campagnolo wheel bags. The all-silver build kit and slimmed-down carbon fork showcases Sam’s impeccable eye for detail. Bravo!

@SingularCycles

Sturdy Cycles Cerakote Fiadh Titanium Road

When it comes to mastering the integration of 3D printing technology, Sturdy Cycles is right up there at the top. Tom Sturdy unveiled a client’s Fiadh road bike at Bespoked UK, with a stark and clean white and gold Cerakote finish job hiding many of the component’s material identities. For instance, the integrated cockpit is all titanium, as is the fork, seatpost, and crankset. While 3D technology has enabled Tom Sturdy to elevate his final product, he mentioned he’s interested in doing more in-house machining in the future, stating he had just finished a crankset before the show he’s proud of.

Late last year, Sturdy announced its Set Size production bikes, using standardized geometries. These Set Size bikes will retail for £4,800, while a custom model like the Fiadh road shown here can fetch a price of £9,600 and up. The Set Size road model is coming later this year…

I cannot emphasize how clean this bike is in person. It’s impeccable, light, and is truly a work of rideable art. The 52-tooth chainring harkens back to an era of 2x race machines, yet it utilizes a Classified hub system to double the gearing spread. The owner, John, has yet to see the bike in person; we hope we don’t ruin the surprise for him! Well done, Tom!

@SturdyCycles

 

 

Well, which build is your favorite? Let us know in the comments!

 

As a thank you to the builders for their time and energy, I’ve uploaded all of these images to The Radavist’s Dropbox for your use!

The Radavist thanks Tailfin for supporting our 2025 Bespoked UK coverage and our independent Reportage!

author: John Watson
